comments_data.body:
> for now I'm throwing a warning if there is more than 1 subtitle selected and continuing with the first one (for audio only, video logics were not changed)

~~That makes sense. Just make sure the other subs (that were not embedded) don't get deleted~~ (As per discussion in discord, multiple can be embedded even if player fails to show them. So do that)

> > So do that

Okay
I will still throw a warning with something like "Even though multiple subs are being Embed, most players are able to display one of them"

@pukkandan I think this pr can be merged
Please have a look
@Grub4K i pushed all the changes that you asked above
Do i need to update docs in this same pr?
What would you (or maybe want to) add into the docs?

there isn't much but the `--embed-subs` usage needs to be updated
![image](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/assets/89282645/9fd99b3e-201c-4ea8-a57b-4afe69ab5743)
and also mentioning that for music `--convert-subs lrc` is mandatory

Changes can be done to `options.py`. Perhaps something like this?
```py
    postproc.add_option(
        '--embed-subs',
        action='store_true', dest='embedsubtitles', default=False,
        help=(
            'Embed subtitles into the downloaded media. '
            'Available for video (mp4, webm and mkv) and audio when using  --convert-subtitles lrc'))
```

> ```python
>             'Available for video (mp4, webm and mkv) and audio when using  --convert-subtitles lrc'))
> ```

`convert-subttiles lrc` seemed like we were talking about both video and audio. so i rephrased it

I have updated both `option.py` and `readme.md`

The impl had a lot of subtle bugs.

* `'data'` need not always be available; read from file
* Don't use filename to detect `ext`; take from infodict
* Don't abort if some subs are not lrc; embed what we can and warn for rest
* Language can be passed for mp3
* `mutagen` may not be installed; proper error should be issued


The whole `run` function is a mess anyway, so I decided to rewrite it completely.
Note to self: Thumbnail and subtitle parts should be merged separately

The current implementation is incorrect. `LRC` metadata cannot be directly embedded in any file format. The only format that supports synced lyrics is mp3, via the `SYLT` tag (which differs from `LRC`, requiring conversion). For other formats, `LRC` data should be written in a file with the same name as the song (e.g., `song.flac` and `song.lrc`).
And what about the unsynced lyrics? I think that the author of the original issue has proposed a pretty good solution https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues/5635#issuecomment-1327879883.

> The current implementation is incorrect. 

Why is that? I'm already using it to download my songs. And it works... Synchronised... 

<details>
<summary>Screenshot</summary>

![Screenshot_2024-02-25-08-20-35-68_345bb2134bfb84a7decceb0b36861421.jpg](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/assets/89282645/978778ab-4100-41ad-bcfa-38a896d6461c)

</details>

Can you point me to some docs or implementations to read? That will really help

> And what about the unsynced lyrics? 

Can you please provide me with a test case where we get unsynced lyrics from yt so that I can do some testing

Maybe it works in some players, but it's certainly not a standard behavior.
1) [MP3](https://web.archive.org/web/20200101074150/http://id3.org/id3v2.4.0-frames). See section 4.9 (Synchronised lyrics/text). Synchronized lyrics format described in this section is not compatible with LRC. So there is no way of embedding synced lyrics in MP3 without converting them to SYLT format. There is also an USLT tag for **unsynced** lyrics. 
2) [OGG/OPUS/FLAC](https://xiph.org/vorbis/doc/v-comment.html). All of these formats use Vorbis Comments, which are very limited. But de facto standard for storing **unsynced** lyrics is the `LYRICS` field.
3) [M4A/MP4](https://exiftool.org/TagNames/QuickTime.html). These formats use QuickTime tags. There is a `lyrics` tag (see "QuickTime UserData Tags" section). There is no description for this tag, but it would be logical to assume that it's  mostly used for the **unsynced** lyrics.

So I think the best way of storing synchronized lyrics for any audio file format is to simply use an LRC. That is, writing `.lrc` file right next to the audio file (as I described earlier, `song.flac` and `song.lrc`). This is supported by wast majority of music players.

> Can you please provide me with a test case where we get unsynced lyrics from yt so that I can do some testing

I can't, because there are no extractors that return unsynced lyrics. We need to add support in `FFmpegEmbedSubtitlePP` at first.

> Maybe it works in some players, but it's certainly not a standard behavior.

I will check these later. It would be good if any maintainer would confirm that implementation is too wrong to be accepted as a solution

> We need to add support in `FFmpegEmbedSubtitlePP` at first. 

Is there any point to solve problems that don't exist? Is there any open pr that will bring such changes?

@someziggyman From my observation it seems recently uploaded videos take some time to get format 22 downloadable.

As I stated in my post (the closed one, see above), this can be spotted. The size appears faulty. yt-dlp should default to download and mix audio+video in such as case.

Instead of format 22, something like this:
`yt-dlp -f '139+136'  "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQaO678_XSg"`
does the trick.

My point being, is that yt-dlp could spot the failure in advance and circumvent the trap.

I have to correct myself. **The missing filesize does NOT IMPLY that the download will fail.** It is only an indicator that the download **MAY** fail.

399 mp4   1920x1080   25 │  34.66MiB 411k https │ av01.0.08M.08 411k video only              1080p, mp4_dash
137 mp4   1920x1080   25 │  57.15MiB 678k https │ avc1.640028   678k video only              1080p, mp4_dash
248 webm  1920x1080   25 │  42.90MiB 509k https │ vp9           509k video only              1080p, webm_dash

yt-dlp -S res:720,ext:mp4:m4a,vcodec:h264,+acodec:m4a,filesize  "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLUNBvSTiM4"
[youtube] NLUNBvSTiM4: Downloading webpage
[youtube] NLUNBvSTiM4: Downloading android player API JSON
[info] NLUNBvSTiM4: Downloading 1 format(s): 22
[download] Destination: Die unfassbare Wahrheit - Ich packe aus! [NLUNBvSTiM4].mp4
[download] 100% of 22.97MiB in 00:17
```

I therefore conclude that **a failing download COULD be averted by looking at the missing filesize**.
The alternative would be to attempt an alternative download (mixing or other format) on “ERROR: Did not get any data blocks”. But this alternative could be costly, as the download only fails “after a while” and what has been downloaded would have to be thrown away then.

I tried adding “**filesize**” to my format string, to see if I could dissuade _yt-dlp_ from going for format 22 in case of a missing (guessed) filesize, but this didn't work:
`yt-dlp -S res:720,ext:mp4:m4a,vcodec:h264,+acodec:m4a,filesize  "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLUNBvSTiM4"`
It still went for format 22, despite its size not showing when printing the available formats (-F).
Did I get that format string with the “filesize” added wrong?

`-S` is for **sorting** formats. Use `-f` for **filtering** them. While -S simplifies a lot of the common functionality of -f, it is not a replacement. You can use both together to get exactly what you need

I reread the manual section about formats and looked at the examples. I appear to be dyslexic when it comes to youtube-dl format strings.
I tried adding -f “filesize>0” after or before the -S string. I also tried without it:
-f "(bv*[filesize>1][height<=720][width<=1280][vcodec=h264][ext=mp4]) / (ba*[acodec=m4a])"
None of it works.

I download the videos for an old HD tablet. It cannot handle newer video or audio formats properly. Hence, I'm trying to download an MP4 in 720p or less, with h264 and “old” (no webm, av1 or anything like that) audio. Where the filesize is only guessed (this issue only seems to occur on YouTube), it should resort to download the video and audio separately, mixing them together, instead (140+139 in this example).
For the time being, the video under https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLUNBvSTiM4 can still serve as an example, as the size for format 22 still reads (22  mp4   1280x720    25 │ ~23.52MiB).
@xxxLCxxx `yt-dlp -f "bv*[filesize>0]+ba" -S ... "URL"`

issues.title: kick.com videos - HTTP Error 403: Forbidden
issues.body:
### DO NOT REMOVE OR SKIP THE ISSUE TEMPLATE

- [X] I understand that I will be **blocked** if I *intentionally* remove or skip any mandatory\* field

### Checklist

- [X] I'm reporting that a **supported** site is broken
- [X] I've verified that I'm running yt-dlp version **2023.03.04** ([update instructions](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp#update)) or later (specify commit)
- [X] I've checked that all provided URLs are playable in a browser with the same IP and same login details
- [X] I've checked that all URLs and arguments with special characters are [properly quoted or escaped](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/wiki/FAQ#video-url-contains-an-ampersand--and-im-getting-some-strange-output-1-2839-or-v-is-not-recognized-as-an-internal-or-external-command)
- [X] I've searched [known issues](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues/3766) and the [bugtracker](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues?q=) for similar issues **including closed ones**. DO NOT post duplicates
- [X] I've read the [guidelines for opening an issue](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#opening-an-issue)
- [X] I've read about [sharing account credentials](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#are-you-willing-to-share-account-details-if-needed) and I'm willing to share it if required

### Region

Sweden

### Provide a description that is worded well enough to be understood

Yt-dlp gets stuck on a 403 forbidden error on kick.com video sites. The site still works and plays in browser but I do get redirected via a cloudflare site which I'm suspecting is the problem. The website version works and plays the video without requiring login on Firefox and Chrome. I'm on the latest 2023.03.04 version of yt-dlp.

Debugging attempts:
Using session cookies via --cookies cookies.txt downloaded through a browser extension does not work. Still getting a 403 error.

Forcing the user agent to be Mozilla via --user-agent "Mozilla/5.0" has no effect. Still getting a 403 error.

Grabbing the m3u8 stream from inspecting memory in browser and downloading it via yt-dlp that way works i.e:
`yt-dlp https://stream.kick.com/ivs/v1/196233775518/LfDRYYsAP6oJ/2023/4/8/2/37/iddbzqX5UQuJ/media/hls/master.m3u8`

Hence it seems to not be able to resolve the website. 

If there is a way to resolve cloudflare I could not find it in the issue tracker and if I missed it I apologize, I don't mean to waste anyone's time. Thank you for all your hard work!

How to reproduce:
`yt-dlp https://kick.com/video/234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e`

Output including error:
`[generic] 234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e: Downloading webpage
ERROR: [generic] Unable to download webpage: HTTP Error 403: Forbidden (caused by <HTTPError 403: 'Forbidden'>); please report this issue on  https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues?q= , filling out the appropriate issue template. Confirm you are on the latest version using  yt-dlp -U`

### Provide verbose output that clearly demonstrates the problem

- [X] Run **your** yt-dlp command with **-vU** flag added (`yt-dlp -vU <your command line>`)
- [ ] If using API, add `'verbose': True` to `YoutubeDL` params instead
- [X] Copy the WHOLE output (starting with `[debug] Command-line config`) and insert it below

### Complete Verbose Output

I'm using the windows executable, not through python.
That's not what your log says. I can't do anything to help if you're not providing a log from the latest version

> That's not what your log says. I can't do anything to help if you're not providing a log from the latest version

I'm sorry but I don't know why the log says that. 
But I am using the windows executable. See my attached images:

![bild](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49168045/230730432-835952e1-4a05-4701-a527-6a02639c7a8b.png)
![bild](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49168045/230730483-2c85a00d-ae56-40fe-b26f-ec31fa02842c.png)

I've pushed a change to the Kick extractor. Now it will continue to try to extract the video if the first request fails.

Here's what you can try:

1. With your yt-dlp win exe, run `yt-dlp --update-to nightly`

2. Try `yt-dlp -v https://kick.com/video/234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e`

3. If that fails, then try navigating to the site in your browser, and passing cookies from browser to yt-dlp:
`yt-dlp -v --cookies-from-browser chrome https://kick.com/video/234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e`
(or replace `chrome` with whatever browser you visit kick.com with)

4. If the above also fails, then find your browser's user-agent string (you can type "what is my user-agent" into duckduckgo or google), and try running:
`yt-dlp -v --user-agent "USER_AGENT" --cookies-from-browser chrome https://kick.com/video/234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e`
(replace `USER_AGENT` with your actual user-agent string)

If successful, please reply with which worked for you (2, 3 or 4)

If you are still getting an error, please post the verbose log as text

Confirm you are on the latest version using  yt-dlp -U

![bild](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49168045/230733853-d5db442e-24ac-433c-9e69-60ea90deb359.png)

While I still can't reproduce the 403 error myself, I am pretty sure that the problem here is cloudflare fingerprinting.

I *can* get a 403 if I send a curl request to `https://kick.com/` with the default curl user-agent:
```
$ curl -f "https://kick.com/"
curl: (22) The requested URL returned error: 403

$ curl --head "https://kick.com/"
HTTP/2 403 
date: Sat, 08 Apr 2023 17:11:04 GMT
content-type: text/html
cross-origin-embedder-policy: require-corp
cross-origin-opener-policy: same-origin
cross-origin-resource-policy: same-origin
permissions-policy: accelerometer=(),autoplay=(),camera=(),clipboard-read=(),clipboard-write=(),fullscreen=(),geolocation=(),gyroscope=(),hid=(),interest-cohort=(),magnetometer=(),microphone=(),payment=(),publickey-credentials-get=(),screen-wake-lock=(),serial=(),sync-xhr=(),usb=()
referrer-policy: same-origin
x-frame-options: SAMEORIGIN
cache-control: private, max-age=0, no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
expires: Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:01 GMT
set-cookie: __cf_bm=Gb_aJJrlyi0gy.V5MYZdgB.uUfrEGSwU.Bt4SuTO0qI-1680973864-0-AQUOPrPVbPLGX+T9ne10ZNgmZIOtelh7HWAdHzoCIVPPSrGSGPhJqVowxxmCI8/XLaFrH4sb25CXC9G9HmJPzMI=; path=/; expires=Sat, 08-Apr-23 17:41:04 GMT; domain=.kick.com; HttpOnly; Secure; SameSite=None
server: cloudflare
cf-ray: 7b4c209d8c5d230f-ORD
alt-svc: h3=":443"; ma=86400, h3-29=":443"; ma=86400
```
...and the body of the response is a captcha challenge page.

crunchyroll implements this same type of fingerprinting, and the steps I had you try were taken from the workaround I discovered when experimenting with the CR extractor back when it was broken:
https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/5294#issuecomment-1289735453
(note the same `__cf_bm` cloudflare cookie being set)

Crunchyroll only shields their API with cloudflare; you can still request the front page of CR and the site will set the cookies necessary to bypass the fingerprinting and access the API with yt-dlp. I tried to do something similar with the Kick extractor, but the difference/problem is that the front page of Kick is shielded by cloudflare, too. 

I'm guessing only certain IP ranges are having their requests screened, which is why some users are affected by this issue and some are not. Not sure about that, though. 

Unfortunately, I don't think there is anything we can do as of right now. With yt-dlp's current capabilities, CF fingerprinting is a problem without a solution

Does `yt-dlp -v --user-agent "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Googlebot/2.1; +http://www.google.com/bot.html)" https://kick.com/video/234e331d-f8bd-4935-b72d-0ec5354a652e` work?

(I spent 10 minutes scrolling through the Discord history to find this :trollface:)

using yt-dlp to download from kick.com fails (403) for me when using a vpn, succeeds when using home IP.
web browser displays kick.com video through vpn.

some sort of fingerprinting issue.

Kick being new can afford to utilize javascript hacks to identify legit users (on low trust IPs), youtube and twitch have apps on myriad of hardware all using the same(?) API for efficiency, any such measures would end up with a lot of upset users.

> I highly doubt this will work, but what happens if you use `--geo-bypass-country XX`, where `XX` is your home country's [two letter code](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-2#Current_codes)?

Nothing happened,  also i tried 3 different vpn end point in 3 different countries to the same effect of 403.
they are probably discriminating against some or all vpn providers, or single out datacenters.
I'd be curious whether they're detecting VPNs, or just only 403ing some countries. What happens if you use a VPN based in your home country?

> I'd be curious whether they're detecting VPNs, or just only 403ing some countries. What happens if you use a VPN based in your home country?

one of the three countries I tested was my country, the other was US and germany.
I'm not using a VPN but I'm situated in Sweden. Appreciate all ideas here but no clue how to work around Cloudflare fingerprinting if that's the problem.
does `--legacy-server-connect` help with this issue?

> does `--legacy-server-connect` help with this issue?

this appears to fix the issue.
just re-verified that the regular approach results in 403, adding --legacy-server-connect results in successful download.

Website works but yt-dlp gets 403'd with the latest nightly.

However, you can still download the VOD by getting the master m3u8 and plugging that into yt-dlp as described in this video guide.

https://streamable.com/xbel1y
I was using yt-dlp to get the HLS url to pass it to my ffmpeg based video player. It was working last week. I tried today with a today git yt-dlp and I get the dreaded 403.

The PR will also need other changes then the ones mentioned in my previous review. If you want to pick this up I would ask you to read our [contributing guide](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-instructions) and adjust the code accordingly. You should also make yourself familiar with python and test any changes yourself. I don't really fancy reviewing completely untested code.

Formatting and linting is also applied through `hatch`
What other changes do you think are necessary that are written in the contributing guide?

The extractor tests currently do not pass. You will need to run them locally. Extractor tests can not be run in the CI due to geo restrictions, account requirements, and datacenter IPs often being blocked.

For the formatting, please particularly take a look at the long line policy: https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#long-lines-policy
A lot of the function calls in this PR have one line per argument and do not use hanging indentation.

Inside the venv you should be able to just run `yt-dlp` to execute from source. Alternatively use `python -m yt_dlp`

I had another look at the code and the current auth implementation does not work anymore(?). We need some additional logic to handle access, video, and refresh tokens. It would probably also be good to cache those instead of having to log-in every time.
We also can not rename `VrtNUIE` to `VRTMAXIE` as that would break compatibility with features such as --download-archive.

If you don't mind I would take over this PR. I should have some time to work on this on the weekend.

Is there anything else that still needs to be done before we can merge (and release) this PR?
I still want to simplify the auth logic. I will push something up once ready.

@seproDev Anything I can do to help out with simplifying the auth?
I'd love to get this PR merged (and released) so people can start downloading VRT MAX videos again

I'm not sure when the next "stable" release will be tagged. Probably within the month.

issues.title: [RadioComercial] Add extractor

labels.name: site-request
labels.description: Request to support a new website

issues.body:
**IMPORTANT**: PRs without the template will be CLOSED

### Description of your *pull request* and other information

<!--

Explanation of your *pull request* in arbitrary form goes here. Please **make sure the description explains the purpose and effect** of your *pull request* and is worded well enough to be understood. Provide as much **context and examples** as possible

-->

This extractor was created specifically for the Portuguese radio station ``Radio Comercial``.
Its main function is to fetch and download podcast episodes.

Presently, it offers two extract functions:
- Downloading individual podcast episodes by directly using their URL links.
- Downloading all the episodes of a specified season for a particular podcast, utilizing the `playlist concept.

Valid URLs that are covered by this extractor:
- Single episode: ``https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/convenca-me-num-minuto/t3/convenca-me-num-minuto-que-os-lobisomens-existem``
- Entire podcast playlist: ``https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/as-minhas-coisas-favoritas``
- Playlist specific to a particular season of a podcast: ``https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/convenca-me-num-minuto/t3``

copilot:all
-->
### <samp>🤖 Generated by Copilot at bd9904c</samp>

### Summary
🎙️📻🎧

<!--
1.  🎙️ - This emoji represents the audio and podcast content that the new extractors can download from Radio Comercial. It also suggests the theme of radio broadcasting and communication, which is relevant for the source website.
2.  📻 - This emoji represents the radio station itself, as well as the medium of radio in general. It also indicates that the new extractors are specific to Radio Comercial and not other radio websites.
3.  🎧 - This emoji represents the listening experience and the enjoyment of the audio content that the new extractors provide. It also suggests the quality and variety of the podcasts and shows that Radio Comercial offers.
-->
This pull request adds two new extractors for `yt-dlp`, `RadioComercialIE` and `RadioComercialPlaylistIE`, which enable downloading audio and playlists from the Portuguese radio station Radio Comercial. It also fixes a minor formatting issue in `_extractors.py`.

> _Oh we are the coders of the sea_
> _And we write extractors with glee_
> _We pull the audio from `RadioComercial`_
> _On the count of three, heave ho, heave ho!_

### Walkthrough
*  Add support for Radio Comercial extractors ([link](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8508/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-780b22dc7eb280f5a7b2bbf79aff17826de88ddcbf2fc1116ba19901827aa4e3R1580-R1583), [link](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8508/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-1e19ea63575bf6d4862897095d1b9e9362bcdca2f4cd9af94926fb911bc7cc0fR1-R141))
   * Import new classes `RadioComercialIE` and `RadioComercialPlaylistIE` from `radiocomercial.py` in `_extractors.py` ([link](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8508/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-780b22dc7eb280f5a7b2bbf79aff17826de88ddcbf2fc1116ba19901827aa4e3R1580-R1583))
   * Define new classes in `radiocomercial.py` that inherit from `RadioComercialBaseExtractor` ([link](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8508/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-1e19ea63575bf6d4862897095d1b9e9362bcdca2f4cd9af94926fb911bc7cc0fR1-R141))
* Remove an empty line from `_extractors.py` for formatting consistency ([link](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8508/files?diff=unified&w=0#diff-780b22dc7eb280f5a7b2bbf79aff17826de88ddcbf2fc1116ba19901827aa4e3L26))



</details>

comments_data.body: Same as https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/8507#issuecomment-1792785496. Please instead edit the description and push additional commits onto the other branch
@seproDev thank you very much for taking the time to look into this, and provide those valuable suggestions. I'm working on those and will update the code once complete.

I'm currently having an issue extracting playlists from the website because of how it deals with unavailable episodes. At first, I was using a Python `set` to gather the episode links from the elements with class `tm-ouvir-podcast`, avoiding the duplicates entries (this class shows up twice for each episode).

The trouble is, any unavailable episode defaults to the same URL (like radiocomercial/podcast/\<season\>). This behaviour can be seen in test number 4 of the `RadioComercialPlaylistIE` class, in which two episodes are unavailable on the same page (first).

This situation leads to two problems:

Problem 1: When I was using a Python set and more than one episode was missing, I ended up with fewer episodes than the expected number (`_PAGE_SIZE`). This stopped the scanning of additional pages. 
To fix this, I changed the code to get rid of the duplicate `tm-ouvir-podcast` classes. Now, I  use lists instead of sets, ensuring the episode count always matches the `_PAGE_SIZE`, by keeping the unavailable episodes entries.

Problem 2: The unavailable episodes cause an error when the downloader tries to process them.: 

```bash
[RadioComercialPlaylist] Playlist TNT - Todos No Top - Temporada 2023: Downloading 41 items of 41
[download] Downloading item 1 of 41
[RadioComercial] Extracting URL: https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/tnt-todos-no-top/2023/t-n-t-29-de-outubro
[RadioComercial] t-n-t-29-de-outubro: Downloading webpage
[info] t-n-t-29-de-outubro: Downloading 1 format(s): 0
[download] Destination: T.N.T 29 de outubro [t-n-t-29-de-outubro].mp3
[download] 100% of   86.69MiB in 00:00:13 at 6.62MiB/s
[download] Downloading item 2 of 41
ERROR: No suitable extractor (RadioComercial) found for URL https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/tnt-todos-no-top/2023/
[download] Downloading item 3 of 41
[RadioComercial] Extracting URL: https://radiocomercial.pt/podcasts/tnt-todos-no-top/2023/t-n-t-15-de-outubro
[RadioComercial] t-n-t-15-de-outubro: Downloading webpage`

I think I initially suggested using a `PagedList` over a generator function 🙃
Sorry about that
@seproDev all good, the issues with using a `PagedList` weren't immediately apparent

> Both of the problems you mentioned mean that a `PagedList` is not a viable option for this playlist extractor.
> 
> Instead we'll need to just use a generator function (e.g. `_entries()`), and we can use `playlist_from_matches()` which casts the URLs to an `orderedSet` and then constructs the `url_result`s for us. We can also use `RadioComercialIE.suitable()` to ensure the URLs are not bogus

Thank you very much for taking the time and providing the proper solution for this use case. This has been a great learning experience so far.

issues.title: All downloads from SBS broken

labels.name: patch-available

### DO NOT REMOVE OR SKIP THE ISSUE TEMPLATE

### Checklist

- [X] I'm reporting that a **supported** site is broken
- [X] I've verified that I'm running yt-dlp version **2023.03.04** ([update instructions](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp#update)) or later (specify commit)
- [X] I've checked that all provided URLs are playable in a browser with the same IP and same login details
- [X] I've checked that all URLs and arguments with special characters are [properly quoted or escaped](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/wiki/FAQ#video-url-contains-an-ampersand--and-im-getting-some-strange-output-1-2839-or-v-is-not-recognized-as-an-internal-or-external-command)
- [X] I've searched [known issues](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues/3766) and the [bugtracker](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues?q=) for similar issues **including closed ones**. DO NOT post duplicates

### Region

Australia

### Provide a description that is worded well enough to be understood

All attempts to download videos from the SBS Ondemand website are now failing with similar errors. A bug report has been posted to the youtube-dl site and the conclusion there was that SBS has "made updates to their streaming platform video obfuscation."

Downloading with yt-dlp does work using the master manifest obtained using a browser addon video stream detector whilst playing the video in a browser.

Note SBS is geoblocked to Australia.

### Provide verbose output that clearly demonstrates the problem

Workaround: use the android HLS
```diff
diff --git a/yt_dlp/extractor/sbs.py b/yt_dlp/extractor/sbs.py
index 45320339d..eb4b918f5 100644
--- a/yt_dlp/extractor/sbs.py
+++ b/yt_dlp/extractor/sbs.py
@@ -91,12 +91,11 @@ def _real_extract(self, url):
             raise ExtractorError('%s said: %s' % (self.IE_NAME, error_message), expected=True)

         urls = player_params['releaseUrls']
-        theplatform_url = (urls.get('progressive') or urls.get('html')
+        theplatform_url = (urls.get('progressive') or urls.get('htmlandroid')
                            or urls.get('standard') or player_params['relatedItemsURL'])

         return {
             '_type': 'url_transparent',
-            'ie_key': 'ThePlatform',
             'id': video_id,
             'url': smuggle_url(self._proto_relative_url(theplatform_url), {'force_smil_url': True}),
             'is_live': player_params.get('streamType') == 'live',
```

I don't expect this to be committed, since the Android HLS could be lower quality (I haven't verified this). As such, I didn't put any effort into this code. If my workaround is deemed acceptable, feel free to ping me (on Discord), and I will happily make a proper PR

gamer191 - I don't know where "smuggle" came from but "youtubedl" appears to have come from your user configuration file, viz:
> [debug] User config "C:\Users\jaybu\AppData\Roaming\yt-dlp\config.txt": ['--ffmpeg-location', 'C:\\Users\\jaybu\\ffmpeg\\bin', '-P', 'C:\\Users\\jaybu\\youtube.dl']

I can't check ATM (at work behind a heavy duty corp firewall), but when I played something last night in a browser (after logging in) and then using a video stream detector, I was able to get the master manifest which yt-dlp was able to happily download. From memory it was via akamai. So the issue isn't actually downloading SBS videos, it is in converting the SBS url for the video into the actual URL, hence the comment on the youtube-dl forum, as in the OP.

Whether related or not, since about 10-14 days ago there has been a mismatch between the reported filesize, data & bit rates for SBS videos and what actually downloads. Since SBS has evidently downgraded the quality of their videos quite a bit by reducing the bit/data rates (as clear via watching them in a browser), this doesn't appear to be a yt-dlp bug so I've not posted an issue. I'm just noting it here as evidence of further changes at SBS and something that may or may not be related to the current issue.

Check the penultimate line of the patch code above to see where the contraband fragment comes from.

This mechanism is used to pass options with a URL from a user-facing extractor (eg SBS) to a video host extractor (eg ThePlatform) through a `url` or `url_transparent` extractor result.

For devs out of region, note that the API used by the extractor isn't geo-blocked, and so the various media links tested in the patch code can easily be inspected.

`player_params['relatedItemsURL']`

This wouldn't be a useful substitute to judge from the one I checked: just a JSON playlist of similar shows.

> player_params['relatedItemsURL']

my patch doesn't touch that line, only the line above it. EDIT: it was added in https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/commit/3c283a381e4f7a69bf57c3ea85aab3c85ce0e309
By the way, my patch is a workaround. I doubt that using the Android hls is an acceptable fix. What do you think?

I downloaded an episode of a daily show using the android work-around and compared it to previous 'normal' ones and it's about 1/3rd smaller in filesize.  Whether that's due to the android 'version' or the SBS video downgrade noted above I can't say though.  I can't say I noticed it being hugely lower quality when I watched it.

From the yt-dl thread, a new API should be used.

The `htmlandroid` links include a `sz` query parameter that implies the size would be ~ 550x300.

>my patch doesn't touch that line, only the line above it. EDIT: it was added in 3c283a3

Sure, I guess the suspect alternative has never been reached.

Thanks for the "[Workaround: use the android HLS](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues/6543#issuecomment-1469966559)" patch (above).  I am relatively new to Python (Windows 10 and Ubuntu 22 via WSL).  Is there a guide as to how I can implement this patch? I can use Git on both of my platforms.  Thanks

> Thanks for the "[Workaround: use the android HLS](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/issues/6543#issuecomment-1469966559)" patch (above). I am relatively new to Python (Windows 10 and Ubuntu 22 via WSL). Is there a guide as to how I can implement this patch? I can use Git on both of my platforms. Thanks

Thanks for the `video_smil?id` tip.  Some powershell semi-pseudo-code :-)   to take an SBS url ($url) and use this tip:
```powershell
$url -match "/(\d+)$" > $null    # get the ID of the item
$id = $Matches[1]
$newurl = "https://www.sbs.com.au/api/v3/video_smil?id=" + $id   # build new URL
$jdata = yt-dlp  --no-warnings -j  $newurl  | ConvertFrom-Json  #get some info on the item 
# title NOT in that json, so build our own filename and ext:
$newName =  "SBS_" + $id + "_" + $jdata.format_id + "_" + $jdata.resolution  + "." + $jdata.ext  
# and finally ...
yt-dlp --no-warnings --quiet --progress $newurl -o $newName
```
Quick and dirty, I'm sure it can be cleaned up.

**_This is step 1/3 of PR https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/pull/4221 ._**

- fix bilibili bangumi, fixes #1878
- fix bangumi playlist support (`BiliBiliBangumiMediaIE`, rename from old `BiliBiliBangumiIE`)
  - old `bangumi.bilibili.com/anime/xxx` do not exist anymore
- drop URL `https://www.bilibili.tv/video/xxxxx`, which is 404 now.
- add real subtitle support
- remove useless backup_url, fixes #4397
- add some metadata
- refine message when video is blocked by geo or premium
- refactor `BiliBiliIE._real_extract` to simplify it, and prepare for other features.
  - split bangumi only logic to new `BiliBiliBangumiIE`
  - simplify aid, cid fetching, fixes #4071
  - simplify tags fetching
  - simplify title and other metadata parsing
  - other refactor

This PR still add ~300 lines (removed ~400 lines), and they are coupled.
Smaller PR will result in moving code block one by one, and will result in many PRs,
so I keep it as a whole, it's easier to review if you only focus on new code but not the diff. 

Left PRs in plan:

Step 2/3: (a small one)
* chapter support
* optimize fps display

Step 3/3:
* support old flv_frags format

comments_data.body:
This failed to get the cid correctly when I tested it today on a (private, so I shall not share it) bluesky post with an embedded video. As is, this branch resulted in an attempt to download a URL with `&cid=None`.

I haven't attempted to read `traverse_obj` or understand how it works, so I don't have a solution per se. But I inserted some debugging code to dump the `post` object. There was a reference to a m3u8 playlist in `post["embed"]["media"]["playlist"]`. No guarantees that naive traversal always works, but it did in my case.

Here's a copy of `post["embed"]` but anonymized:

```json
{"$type": "app.bsky.embed.recordWithMedia#view", "media": {"$type": "app.bsky.embed.video#view", "cid": "somecid", "playlist": "https://video.bsky.app/watch/did%3Aplc%3A<something>/somecid/playlist.m3u8", "thumbnail": "https://video.bsky.app/watch/did%3Aplc%3A<something>/somecid/thumbnail.jpg", "aspectRatio": {"height": 1080, "width": 1920}}
```

I re-ran yt-dlp on that m3u8 URL and got what I wanted.

Just noticed the playlist stuff already there. I'm not willing to spend the time going through the rigmarole necessary to fork and submit a PR to the bluesky branch, but the changes were simple:

1. traversals from embed -> playlist and embed -> thumbnail should have a middle "media" step, e.g., `traverse_obj(post, ('embed', 'media', 'playlist'))`
2. if `blob_cid` is falsey, don't append to `formats`

That worked fine for my single URL of interest.

The correct CID can be obtained from
``` python
post["embed"]["video"]["ref"]["$link"] or
post["embed"]["video"]["cid"]
```

Sometimes there's an extra `media` in `embed`. In that case
``` python
post["embed"]["media"]["video"]["ref"]["$link"] or
post["embed"]["media"]["video"]["cid"]
```

This seems to work for gallery-dl, at least (https://github.com/mikf/gallery-dl/commit/4c391805de49c7b7f1b98357c2bd0096a5e88fce).

Updated to include the above paths (with the slight tweak that we go through "record" first, which gallery-dl also does). For example:
```python
post["record"]["embed"]["video"]["ref"]["$link"]
```
@gavinbeatty your example should work now if the post only has the m3u8 playlist. Thanks!
Yep, your branch works for me now, thanks 👍

Thanks for the redesign @seproDev! I made a few modifications before committing:
- A raise_no_formats was added if no entries are found
- I modified the `traverse_obj` in `get_service_endpoint` (it was always returning the default before)
- A test was added for an at-uri (lovely touch!).
- Added a language field to the info dict. Because it's supposed to be a language code string and not a list of languages, I just grab the first one.

Happy to make whatever changes are needed to help you get this ready for the next release, and I'm the one who should apologize for this taking so long :)

issues.title: [extractor/crunchyroll] Rewrite internals and endpoint usage
issues.body:

<!--

Explanation of your *pull request* in arbitrary form goes here. Please **make sure the description explains the purpose and effect** of your *pull request* and is worded well enough to be understood. Provide as much **context and examples** as possible

-->

Changes:
- Added support for music and artists, movies and movie listings
- ~~Does not retrieve signed policy anymore, and should therefore do one less request for episodes~~
    - Turns out you get softbanned for requesting too much on the streams endpoint, so reverted to signed policy where it makes sense
- ~~Introduces a different caching strategy to prevent a login bug, which makes show => episode do a duplicated main page request~~
    - Login bug has been reintroduced since apparently its common in yt-dlp
- Add various helpers into each class simplifying some of the code
- The show playlist now additionally extracts description
- Show playlist items now extract the same data as the single episode one, except for rating and chapters

Would want a review from @tejing1 to make sure this is not doing something absurd.

comments_data.body:
I'm still going over the code in detail, but I do have one immediate concern: The response from `auth/v1/token` claims it expires in 5 minutes. Before, this didn't matter, since the api requests were actually authenticated by the policy, and that lasts like 24 hours or something. With the policy not in the picture anymore, you may need to track that timeout and re-authenticate when it has expired. Otherwise, playlist downloads will probably fail.

Also, it's been on my mind because movie support isn't implemented yet, but perhaps we should be using the `objects` endpoint rather than `episodes`, as that is in fact what the browser does, and it will be needed to properly support movies, since their urls look the same as episodes, but they don't fall under the `episodes` endpoint.

I'm pleasantly surprised that we can now get rid of the signed policy request, and I definitely feel the `_call_api` structure is an improvement.

Edit: ~~We're also still retrieving the main page twice when using credentials. Once to get a session id for login, and another time to get the `locale` and `cxApiParams`. Any chance we can consolidate those in that case?~~ Faulty memory, sorry.

Confirming that the timeout *is* a problem. I tried downloading a full 12 episode season, and only got a few episodes.

I think it might make more sense to use a fallback to objects (or the dedicated api call if possible) instead. The `objects` endpoint gives way less metadata, meaning we would have to do one more request per episode to resolve the data. While we can do that using the `linked_resource_key` (`cms:/episodes/{id}`) I am hesitant to slow down the extraction like that. Do you have an example of a movie url? Maybe we can find a better, cheaper way to resolve this.

Did you check under `episode_metadata`? It looks like it contains everything. I know the browser never actually uses the `episodes` endpoint at all, so everything it needs to show the video's page is in the `objects` result somewhere.

That seems to be correct. I must have missed it when working on it yesterday somehow, and ended up reverting... If movie metadata does not follow the same (somewhat) structure it might make sense to extract out metadata generation into functions. ~~I would need a movie/other url for testing purposes before making these changes~~ Found <https://www.crunchyroll.com/watch/G62PEZ2E6/garakowa--restore-the-world->.

Additionally we could support music videos. Will use <https://www.crunchyroll.com/watch/musicvideo/MV107DAD58/re-bon-voyage> as a base.
Was going to suggest https://www.crunchyroll.com/watch/G71FD19ZX/jin-roh, but yours works too. And I didn't realize music videos were yet another object type on crunchyroll. There's always something.

What is your opinion on using the internal id instead of the slug as the id shown? Currently if the slug is not in the url it will not be shown. The internal ID must always be in the url, and will therefore always be present in the output as well

It's just that it's utterly meaningless to the human reading the output, while the slug is generally at least a little meaningful. But then again, the id is guaranteed to be unique, and the slug isn't... I see the arguments either way.

Worse, you can actually provide a totally unrelated slug and everything will work, but show the strange slug as the id, so actually we probably shouldn't rely on that part of the url at all...

I have also noticed that for the newly added test, the Intro chapter is wrongly labeled (The main part is labeled as the intro). I doubt we can do anything about it but maybe use unlabeled chapters alltogether? Or just take the shorter of the two as the intro?

Music videos and related use `content/v2/music` 😵‍💫. I will push music support back until after the refactor of the structure and adapt the `_call_api` function to respect that endpoint through a class override.

Regarding the intro thing, the source data just labels the intro start and end times, rather than a sequence of chapters. If crunchyroll has bad data there, I don't think we should be trying to "be smart" and fix it.

Interesting. https://www.crunchyroll.com/watch/G71FD19ZX/jin-roh returns object type `movie`, rather than `movie_listing`, triggering the "unkown object type" message. I wonder what the difference is?

That page 404s for me when trying to view it in a browser, same when trying to ask the `objects/` endpoint about it. The `movie_listing` might be one movie with its trailers, while a `movie` could just be a single one? The one I was an indirect link to `G25FVGDEK`, a ~1 minute trailer only., wich refs to the other 4 media items.

Can you send the `objects` endpoint response for me to investigate?

Guess it's a region thing.
[G71FD19ZX_https_-_www.crunchyroll.com_content_v2_cms_objects_G71FD19ZXlocale=en-US.dump.txt](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/files/10748943/G71FD19ZX_https_-_www.crunchyroll.com_content_v2_cms_objects_G71FD19ZXlocale.en-US.dump.txt)

https://www.crunchyroll.com/watch/GM8F313NQ/garakowa--restore-the-world- also seems to return type `movie`. I got there from your link in the browser by selecting the one listed item with a long runtime.

That seems to be close to what I thought in the beginning. Seems like a case for `--no-playlist` maybe? I think it makes sense to implement a single, direct movie link first and then worry about listings.

I can't seem to get from the listing to the main movie. While we can use `cms:/movie_listings/G62PEZ2E6/movies` to get all media items, the main movie does not have a different metadata to make it stand out.

Maybe we just take all as a playlist when its a trailer, otherwise if `--no-playlist` resolve the current id (when using listing id that is the FIRST, not neccesarily the movie).
When we get a direct movie url, we dont resolve back to the listing, so if they want the main movie only, they could pass the movie url directly.

> I can't seem to get from the listing to the main movie. While we can use cms:/movie_listings/G62PEZ2E6/movies to get all media items, the main movie does not have a different metadata to make it stand out.

I suspect this is because in some cases there are multiple "main movies" due to subbed vs dubbed versions and the like.

I just realized, everytime we specify a direct link, even if trailer, it resolves as `movie`. So I think it's fair to treat just the listing url as a playlist and all the others as single ones. In the worst case we can resolve it back to the listing if people want.
Sorry for the stupid question, but how do I implement this fix? Do I modify the extractor? If so, how and where is the location? I am using the Homebrew Formulae.

Movie support looks good.

Any way we can avoid re-authorizing for the playlist and videos? You mentioned that in the original description, but it still seems to be doing it...

Maybe by attaching the data to the `CrunchyrollBaseIE` class itself, rather than as an instance variable?

issues.title: Subtitle extraction from streaming media manifests (HLS, DASH, Smooth Streaming)
issues.body:
Initially adapted from ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6144. After submitting this PR, I also added extraction from DASH and Smooth Streaming manifests and converted more extractors. The ComCarCoff extractor has been removed since the original PR was submitted upstream, but I tested the manifest parsers with most of the extractors that I also modified in this one. I have not tested this on any live streams; I doubt any of the downloaders work with those.

Not all extractors have been converted to pick up subtitle tracks from streaming manifests; instead, to facilitate incremental porting and maintain compatibility with upstream extractors, wrappers have been added that discard any subtitle tracks and only return audio and video streams. Those wrappers will report a warning if any subtitle tracks are detected that couldn’t be returned, to ease diagnosis and identification of potential porting targets. More potential sites can be found by searching through the upstream issue tracker: https://github.com/ytdl-org/youtube-dl/issues?q=%22Unknown+MIME+type+application%2Fmp4+in+DASH+manifest%22

This PR should (in some cases partially) resolve or subsume the following:

- #73 
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6106
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#6144
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14630
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14635
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14977
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#15424 (not tested)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#18267 (not tested)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#21438 (duplicate of 27899 later)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#22379 (not tested; and only partially, as only the subtitle part was addressed)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23557
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23609
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#23899 (not tested; as there is no dedicated extractor for mubi.com, this is only so far as the generic extractor supports it)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24375
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24517
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24595 (note: DASH-segmented subtitle downloads are unusable, HLS-segmented ones are okay)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24886
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27215 (not tested; partially, as extraction fixes are not included, but those can be cherry-picked without a conflict)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#27899 (partially; decryption has not been ~~implemented~~ tested to work)
- ytdl-org/youtube-dl#28132

----

Test streams:

- HLS:
  - https://devstreaming-cdn.apple.com/videos/streaming/examples/bipbop_16x9/bipbop_16x9_variant.m3u8
  - https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.m3u8
- DASH:
  - http://rdmedia.bbc.co.uk/dash/ondemand/elephants_dream/ (TTML)
  - https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.mpd (TTML)
- Smooth Streaming:
  - https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/Manifest (TTML)

----

Remaining issues:

- [x] HLS subtitle support
  - [x] Assembling on the fly, without keeping temporary files around
  - [x] ~~AES support~~: untested, but should work as long as it works the same way as normal streams
  - [x] Correctness of timestamp adjustment against `X-TIMESTAMP-MAP`
  - [x] Cue deduplication (how many can be duplicated between segments, is deduplication even necessary)
  - [x] ~~Handling of late header blocks~~: we leave a warning, might need to revisit this later
  - [x] ~~Handling of direct links to subtitle streams~~: postponed to a future pull request
- [x] DASH subtitle support
  - [x] ~~Playability of assembled DASH subtitles~~: postponed
- [x] Smooth Streaming subtitle support
  - [x] ~~Playability and validity of assembled SSTR subtitles~~: postponed
- [x] ~~Migration of remaining extractors~~: we keep the compat wrappers, further extractors will be migrated incrementally; no more will be migrated in this pull request
- [x] ~~Language code normalisation~~: postponed
- [x] Alternative stream URL in the Rooster Teeth extractor

comments_data.body: A sample video is available at <https://devstreaming-cdn.apple.com/videos/streaming/examples/bipbop_16x9/bipbop_16x9_variant.m3u8>, but I had some trouble integrating it as a test case.

I am not too familiar with the various manifest specifications, so it'd be very helpfull if you could clarify a few things for me.

1. Is it guaranteed that only webtt will be present in m3u8s? does it not support other formats?
2. Is a separate downloader necessary? Or, can we extend the hls downloader itself to support this?
3. Can this be extended to mpd/ism as well?
4. I see that you are sorting the subs by timestamps at the end. Is this needed? I assumed subtitles will already be in the correct order. If this is not needed, we can write each fragment to the main file as it is downloaded and don't need to wait till the end.

> A sample video is available at https://devstreaming-cdn.apple.com/videos/streaming/examples/bipbop_16x9/bipbop_16x9_variant.m3u8, but I had some trouble integrating it as a test case.

What is the difficulty that you are having?

> Is it guaranteed that only webtt will be present in m3u8s? does it not support other formats?

By my reading of [RFC 8216](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8216), yes. §3.1 says ‘All Media Segments MUST be in a format described in this section.’, and section 3 specifically lists MPEG-2 TS, MPEG-4 fragments, Packed Audio and WebVTT as those supported formats.

> Is a separate downloader necessary? Or, can we extend the hls downloader itself to support this?

It may be possible, I just haven’t really tried. Back when I wrote this, I figured it would be easier to write a new fragmentary downloader instead of disentangling all the logic specific to MPEG-4 multiplexing. But you’d probably still have to have it signalled in advance that you’re downloading a subtitle stream to trigger muxing into the correct target container.

Re-writing the downloader may very well be warranted; I’m not terribly proud of my WebVTT parsing code either.

> Can this be extended to mpd/ism as well?

Doubtful. Those will probably have to be added separately. But you’d have to look it up in the relevant specifications.

> I see that you are sorting the subs by timestamps at the end. Is this needed? I assumed subtitles will already be in the correct order. If this is not needed, we can write each fragment to the main file as it is downloaded and don't need to wait till the end.

We probably can. I don’t remember now what prompted me to add the sorting logic back then. Pay attention to deduplication, though: sometimes a single subtitle cue may appear in two different fragments.

> What is the difficulty that you are having?

I used the `-j` option to obtain the stream info, pasted it into `_TEST_CASES` in `TestInfoExtractor.test_parse_m3u8_formats`, downloaded the manifest into `test/testdata/m3u8/` and… the test failed. The runner told me the the stream info did not match. I also noticed the output of `-j` is much more thorough than in the other test case, so I imagine it might need trimming.

Preferably there should be some kind of test case generator, but I didn’t notice any.
Added a fix for ytdl-org/youtube-dl#14977.

Thanks for all the clarification and sorry for the delay in replying

---

> I used the -j option to obtain the stream info, pasted it into _TEST_CASES in TestInfoExtractor.test_parse_m3u8_formats, downloaded the manifest into test/testdata/m3u8/ and… the test failed.

The `-j` output is not the same as what `_parse_m3u8_formats` returns. It is further processed. If you are having trouble figuring out which keys are needed, add the failing test, and I'll clean up the test

---

> > Is a separate downloader necessary? Or, can we extend the hls downloader itself to support this?

> It may be possible, I just haven’t really tried.

ok, for the time-being, lets work on this as a separate downloader. If we end up with too much copy-paste code from the hls downloader, we can look into merging them

---

> We probably can. I don’t remember now what prompted me to add the sorting logic back then. Pay attention to deduplication, though: sometimes a single subtitle cue may appear in two different fragments.

Yes, I did notice the duplication in the example you gave. I am going to assume the sorting isn't needed and will push a commit later to append each fragment right after it finishes downloading. For the de-dup, are we sure we need to look only one subtitle back? or is it possible to have 2 or more `cues` duplicated?

---

I forgot to ask this last time. Can subtitles not have `AES`/`DRM`? I don't see any checks in the code for these

---

btw, please fix the linter. Don't mind the jython failure. It is a server side issue

No worries, I’m not in a rush.

> Can subtitles not have AES/DRM?

I have not encountered any that do. But the RFC doesn’t seem to forbid it either: encryption and segment type seem to be orthogonal.

> For the de-dup, are we sure we need to look only one subtitle back? or is it possible to have 2 or more cues duplicated?

The spec doesn’t make it clear whether duplication is allowed. The most relevant fragment of the RFC seems to be this:

> Each Media Segment MUST carry the continuation of the encoded bitstream from the end of the segment with the previous Media Sequence Number, where values in a series such as timestamps and Continuity Counters MUST continue uninterrupted.

It seems to imply there should not be any overlap between segments, but even then, it may happen that a segment boundary lies between the beginning and ending timestamps of a cue, which means that a cue logically belongs to both segments. This may be further complicated if cues are not monotonic and multiple may be active at a single timestamp. I don’t know if this is allowed. In the wild, I have only ever found examples where cues are monotonic and only a single cue is shared by two segments.

> btw, please fix the linter.

By uninstalling it?

I already fixed some lints, but as for the ones I left behind, I think following those is not merely unnecessary pedantry, but actively harmful. It would make the code less readable and I would rather turn them off.

(The timestamp parser is much more readable with the alignments than it would have been otherwise. I also avoided re-aligning the parameter list of `_extract_m3u8_formats_and_subtitles` in order to minimise the diff context.)

----

One other thing that makes me worried: the timestamp adjustment I do here is not necessarily correct. It is based on the assumption that PES timestamp zero is the same as the starting time of the stream, but this is not necessarily correct. Especially that the HLS RFC warns:

> When synchronizing WebVTT with PES timestamps, clients SHOULD account for cases where the 33-bit PES timestamps have wrapped and the WebVTT cue times have not.

~~33 bits of millisecond range seems to span 7 years, so timestamp overflow by itself seems unlikely to lead to problems in practice~~ (It’s actually just over a day; PES timestamps have 90 kHz, i.e. ~11 µs resolution. Overflow is still rather unlikely, though not as much as I expected.). The timestamps may still mismatch if the subtitle segments and regular media segments are not perfectly synchronised, e.g. in a live stream.

I managed to find an MPD manifest with subtitles I could test against after all. And even some working code. So I generalised it a bit and included it in this PR. So this is going to cover ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24517 and ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24375 as well.

Added a fix for ytdl-org/youtube-dl#24595 (partial). This one is particularly interesting in that the subtitles in the MPD manifest are apparently also segmented, but unlike HLS, they are wrapped in an mp4 container (the MIME type is given as `application/mp4`); this is not supported yet. HLS manifest extraction works fine.

I managed to adapt the MPD extractor to support segmented subtitles; it was pretty easy. They seem to download fine into an `mp4` container. There is only one problem: they aren’t actually playable. FFmpeg seems to support neither TTML nor WebVTT subtitles embedded in an MPEG-4 container; the former are identified as a ‘data’ stream by `ffprobe`, not as subtitles, and the latter as a corrupt file. And that’s assuming those are even correctly identified as subtitles in the first place. Once I encountered an MPD manifest in which the subtitle elements pointed to… the video stream.

Smooth Streaming subtitle downloading could also be attempted, but without the ability to play back the subtitles it won’t go too far. Extraction from the manifest is just as easy as with MPD, but subsequent downloading would require either:
- extracting subtitles from the MPEG-4 framing and re-muxing them into standalone files, which would have to be done from scratch, or
- digging into the specs to understand how to construct a correct `isml` header with codec metadata, which would result in an unplayable file anyway.

A copy of Sintel for testing:

- HLS: https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.m3u8
- DASH: https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/manifest.mpd
- SSTR: https://sdn-global-streaming-cache-3qsdn.akamaized.net/stream/3144/files/17/07/672975/3144-kZT4LWMQw6Rh7Kpd.ism/Manifest

I noticed that while the assembled TTML subtitles are still unplayable, they seem to be superficially well-formed enough for `ffmpeg -i - -f data -map 0` to be able to dump the XML cues. Those can then be merged into a single file and played, as long as you have a player that supports TTML. VLC will do fine.

Interestingly, VLC can recognise directly assembled DASH subtitles as such, but will not display them, while assembled SSTR subtitles are not recognised at all. I don’t know if this is a problem on VLC’s side or ours.

I re-wrote the WebVTT segment parser and integrated it into the regular HLS downloader. It is now able to take advantage of improvements to the latter, like assembling the output file on the fly. This *may* be enough to enable AES support, but I have nothing to test it on.

I was extremely busy today with irl work, and probably will be tomorrow too. And since this is a pretty large PR, I wont be able to thoroughly review this atleast till wednesday.

On a sidenote, please try not to force push. It makes me have to go through the entire code again.. Maintaining a clean commit history is not necessary. I "squash and merge" PRs and I can remove any pointless commit messages in the process
Take your time, no worries. I think I’m done with it for now.

Perhaps it might make sense to spin off extractor migrations into a separate pull request to make reviewing more manageable?

Also, with a change this large, it seems a bad idea to squash it into a single commit. Imagine you might want to revert or bisect just one of these individual changes at some point…

> Perhaps it might make sense to spin off extractor migrations into a separate pull request to make reviewing more manageable?

Reviewing is fine since the changes in most files are minimal

> Also, with a change this large, it seems a bad idea to squash it into a single commit. Imagine you might want to revert or bisect just one of these individual changes at some point…

I agree. I always squash-merge because I seriously dislike non-linear history. But in this case, squashing everything into one commit does seem like a bad idea. Maybe we can split this PR into smaller chunks and then merge them as separate commits. I am open to suggestions. But for the time-being, let it stay as a single PR

If you want a linear history, you can just rebase without squashing. It’s not like GitHub forces you to use the same kind of merge method everywhere.

You can compare the parser against the [WebVTT spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/webvtt1/). Some syntax descriptions in the spec don’t seem very precise, especially with regard to where and how many newlines are supposed to appear. The `X-TIMESTAMP-MAP` extension is described in [RFC 8216 §3.5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8216#section-3.5), but it doesn’t precisely describe where it fits in the structure of the WebVTT file. It doesn’t give a formal grammar production for it either; I wrote the parser based on usages I found in the wild, which seem to slightly contradict the RFC (it suggests the `LOCAL:` timestamp should go before `MPEGTS:`, but I have usually seen the opposite).

I think this could be merged as-is now. Detailed status:

- Deduplication has been reinstated. The new method should cover arbitrary duplications, as long as the subtitle stream honours the timestamp constraints from the specification (monotonically increasing start timestamps, end timestamps later than start timestamps); in the most common case of non-overlapping cues it only needs to keep one item in the cue queue.
- There is nothing I can test decryption on, but if it worked for audio and video streams, I guess it should work on subtitles too, as long as the encryption works the same way. I’d risk just testing it ‘in the field’, so to speak.
- I conjecture that the assembled DASH and SSTR subtitles streams are correct, even though FFmpeg and VLC cannot currently play them. I think conversion into an actually playable format should be done in a separate pull request, as this one is already quite big.
- As for timestamp adjustment, I leave the mapping of the inital segment inside the file, just in case, so that if the media stream is downloaded with PTS timestamps preserved, it can still be re-aligned with the subtitle file offline, even if the starting instants of the stream doesn’t match up with the subtitle. A mapping of zero to zero is treated as identity and omitted. I’ve also added overflow handling, as unlikely as the situation is. I mean, in the worst case the user can just adjust the timestamps manually anyway, it’s not that big of a deal.

> * This is currently only returning formats

I added the subtitles dictionary, but this particular code path is meant for direct links to single-quality streams, which means it will always be empty anyway. Unless…

> * I saw a test with `http://replayftv-pmd.francetv.fr/subtitles/2017/16/156589847-1492488987.m3u8` in your old PR on youtube-dl. This however doesn't work right now

This is a direct link to a subtitle stream, which, with the fix, is now misidentified as a video stream. There is no way to detect this from manifest contents alone other than by sniffing fragment file extensions. But even if I correctly identified it as a subtitle stream, `yt-dlp` would treat an attempt to download this URL directly as an error, as there are no video or audio streams to be found.

Perhaps it would make sense to merge audio, video and subtitle tracks into a single list for the purposes of format selection. But that’s for another day.

> There is no way to detect this from manifest contents alone other than by sniffing fragment file extensions. 

It is not necessary to implement this in this PR

> But even if I correctly identified it as a subtitle stream, yt-dlp would treat an attempt to download this URL directly as an error, as there are no video or audio streams to be found

But if it is implemented, user can chose to ignore the "no video formats" error using `--ignore-no-formats-error` so that other data such as subtitles can be retrieved even when there is no video formats available

Besides, right now, those subs are detected as a video format which should be considered as a bug (though not one necessarily in the scope of this PR)

@fstirlitz Please do not force push! It makes it very hard for me to keep track of the changes you are making and I am having to review large parts of the code repeatedly. We can clean up the git history at the end once we are done making changes

issues.title: [Announcement] Dropping support for Python 3.8
issues.body:
### [Python 3.8 will reach its end-of-life in October 2024](https://devguide.python.org/versions/). 
Continuing yt-dlp's alignment of Python version support with their official support lifetimes, **yt-dlp will be dropping support for 3.8 shortly thereafter.**

This alignment of support is done primarily for two reasons:

1. yt-dlp's Python dependencies have followed (and most likely *will* follow) a similar trajectory of Python version support; we don't want to get stuck supporting an older version of Python than `urllib3` does, for example.
2. To provide a predictable timeline for the developers and users who utilize the yt-dlp Python package.

---

**🚨IMPORTANT🚨:** This will increase the minimum required Windows version to Windows 8; the yt-dlp release executables will no longer support Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2.

Users on Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 will need to consider alternative options such as @nicolaasjan['s unofficial builds](https://github.com/nicolaasjan/yt-dlp/releases) if upgrading your operating system is not possible.
([See the discussion thread for nicolaasjan's unofficial builds](https://msfn.org/board/topic/184368-who-here-has-a-youtube-dl-compile-for-winxp/))

If you are a Linux user whose system's Python cannot be upgraded beyond 3.8, then you should be able to use the [standalone linux binary, `yt-dlp_linux`](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/releases/latest/download/yt-dlp_linux) (if you are on an x86_64/amd64 system). There are also Linux builds for [armv7](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/releases/latest/download/yt-dlp_linux_armv7l) and [aarch64](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/releases/latest/download/yt-dlp_linux_aarch64) architectures available.

---

The change will allow us to take advantage of these new Python features:

- [PEP 584](https://peps.python.org/pep-0584/), union operators added to dict
- [PEP 616](https://peps.python.org/pep-0616/), string methods to remove prefixes and suffixes: `str.removeprefix()` and `str.removesuffix()`
	- (No real benefit over our `utils.remove_start` and `utils.remove_end` though)
- [PEP 615](https://peps.python.org/pep-0615/), the IANA Time Zone Database is now present in the standard library in the `zoneinfo` module

---

**NOTE**: Python versions 3.9 through 3.12 all support Windows 8. Since operating system support will remain constant until we drop support for 3.12, this is the last minimum Python version requirement bump that will necessitate this level of advance warning until then. Going forward, it should be assumed that yt-dlp will be aligned with the official support cycles of Python versions **unless** announced otherwise.

The installers are at https://github.com/adang1345/PythonWin7. They not only have the OS check removed but also automatically provide `api-ms-win-core-path-l1-1-0.dll`.

@nicolaasjan The linked issue states that Python 3.9 does not support Windows 8 either, which conflicts with [what python.org says](https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/). Can you confirm this? Does the OP of this discussion need to be updated?

@bashonly
I think the poster of that issue is a bit confused.

[Windows 8.1 end of support on January 10, 2023](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/lifecycle/announcements/windows-8-1-end-support-january-2023).

When Python 3.9 was first released (Oct. 5 2020), Windows 8 and 8.1 still had support.

> When Python 3.9 was first released (Oct. 5 2020), Windows 8 and 8.1 still had support.

Are you sure? After a lot of digging, I was able to find https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/21661, which was definitely merged before the first Python 3.9 release (it's a backport of https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/21656)



> Does the OP of this discussion need to be updated?

@bashonly it probably should be updated, but keep in mind that most Windows 8 users will likely be using Windows 8.1, and not Windows 8.0

Yes, this means the official standalone yt-dlp builds will no longer be working on Windows 7.

and could that -U switch be removed from that fork so i don't accidently use it? such scenario definitely can and will happen since i used -U to update yt-dlp for ages.

and on https://github.com/nicolaasjan/yt-dlp/releases i saw several yt-dlp versions different from official yt-dlp, like [2024.09.26.173212](https://github.com/nicolaasjan/yt-dlp/releases/tag/2024.09.26.173212), [2024.09.20.154646](https://github.com/nicolaasjan/yt-dlp/releases/tag/2024.09.20.154646), [2024.08.22.165240](https://github.com/nicolaasjan/yt-dlp/releases/tag/2024.08.22.165240) and so on... are these nightly builds? because latest official yt-dlp (prior to 2024.09.27) was [yt-dlp 2024.08.06](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/releases/tag/2024.08.06), there were no versions for 2024.09.26, 2024.09.20, 2024.08.22 and so on...
so if updating that yt-dlp fork, how can i be sure only getting versions matching official releases of yt-dlp and not any nightly builds?

or coulnd't these changes made the fork working not also be implemented in official yt-dlp to make it still work on windows 7? then i wouldn't have to use any fork of yt-dlp!

and when support for windows 7 ends also for standalone, what about the standalone version for linux mint 19 tara? will this also stop working?

Windows 7 is end of life and you are taking the work of using it yourself. Having to maintain these changes, especially for legacy software, will make it harder for us. Suggestions, like removing `-U`, should be voiced at the repos issue tracker directly.

In my opinion any conversation regarding this should happen on that repo. If @nicolaasjan wishes, we can however keep this issue open instead.

>or coulnd't these changes made the fork working not also be implemented in official yt-dlp to make it still work on windows 7?

The fork uses a hacked together, unofficial cpython version. We will not be using that for official builds.

yt-dlp V2024.09.27
use Python 3.8 or Python 3.9 ?

Which one for Windows 7 ?
yt-dlp 2024.08.06
yt-dlp 2024.09.27

V2024.09.27 is still fully compatible with Python 3.8, and the Windows builds are still made with Python 3.8. This will likely be the last yt-dlp release before Python 3.9 will become the new required minimum version.

> In my opinion any conversation regarding this should happen on that repo. If @nicolaasjan wishes, we can however keep this issue open instead.

I don't mind if this issue is eventually closed.
Any questions and issues regarding yt-dlp on old Windows operating systems can be asked in the [dedicated MSFN forum thread](https://msfn.org/board/topic/184368-who-here-has-a-youtube-dl-compile-for-winxp/).

issues.title: [Allstar] Add extractor

issues.body:
**IMPORTANT**: PRs without the template will be CLOSED

### Description of your *pull request* and other information

<!--

Explanation of your *pull request* in arbitrary form goes here. Please **make sure the description explains the purpose and effect** of your *pull request* and is worded well enough to be understood. Provide as much **context and examples** as possible

-->

add extractor for allstar.gg that support single video and profile.

Fixes #6917


<details open><summary>Template</summary> <!-- OPEN is intentional -->

<!--

# PLEASE FOLLOW THE GUIDE BELOW

- You will be asked some questions, please read them **carefully** and answer honestly
- Put an `x` into all the boxes `[ ]` relevant to your *pull request* (like [x])
- Use *Preview* tab to see how your *pull request* will actually look like

-->

### Before submitting a *pull request* make sure you have:
- [x] At least skimmed through [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-instructions) including [yt-dlp coding conventions](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#yt-dlp-coding-conventions)
- [x] [Searched](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/search?q=is%3Apr&type=Issues) the bugtracker for similar pull requests
- [x] Checked the code with [flake8](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/flake8) and [ran relevant tests](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-instructions)

### In order to be accepted and merged into yt-dlp each piece of code must be in public domain or released under [Unlicense](http://unlicense.org/). Check all of the following options that apply:
- [x] I am the original author of this code and I am willing to release it under [Unlicense](http://unlicense.org/)
- [ ] I am not the original author of this code but it is in public domain or released under [Unlicense](http://unlicense.org/) (provide reliable evidence)

### What is the purpose of your *pull request*?
- [ ] Fix or improvement to an extractor (Make sure to add/update tests)

issues.title: [extractor/goplay] Fix GoPlay downloads
issues.body:
**IMPORTANT**: PRs without the template will be CLOSED

### Description of your *pull request* and other information

This PR fixes two issues with the GoPlay extractor for recent broadcasts:

1. Adds support for the Google streaming platform (dai.google.com with server-side ad insertion, SSAI);
2. Fixes the download of multi-period MPD streams by merging the periods.

Point 1 is fairly straightforward: the metadata JSON provides a new `ssai` field that points to the `manifest.mpd`. See also [this recent change](https://github.com/retrospect-addon/plugin.video.retrospect/commit/b41af9f7b7c79ddb4b09f9dced31d37363d9e9c4) in the Retrospect Kodi addon.

Point 2 is more difficult. The GoPlay manifests split programmes in multiple periods (e.g., three parts with ads in between). The current [MPD implementation](https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp/blob/0f0875ed555514f32522a0f30554fb08825d5124/yt_dlp/extractor/common.py#L2500-L2502) ignores the period division and lists all streams in a single list of formats. As a result, there are usually three audio and three video streams with the highest quality. By default, yt-dlp downloads only one audio and one video stream: this is only one period of the programme, and sometimes the audio does not match the video.

This PR fixes this issue at the GoPlay extractor level, by merging the `fragments` lists of the same format in different periods. The end result is a formats list with only one stream for each format that combines all periods.

It might be better to solve this at the MPD download level instead of in the GoPlay extractor. I assume that this is a general problem for any MPD manifest with multiple periods. But that is a separate issue and might require larger changes in how yt-dlp works.

Fixes #6235.

> But that is a separate issue and might require larger changes in how yt-dlp works.

> 
> As far as I can tell, you just need to move `_merge_mpd_periods` into `_parse_mpd_formats_and_subtitles`. Am I missing something?

@pukkandan Yes, that would work in this case, but this would also change it for all other extractors that use that code. Is merging periods something that should happen everywhere? It might make sense, but I don't know if there are cases where you'd like to have the periods separately. I also don't know how this would work for livestreams.

In short: yes, it would work for GoPlay and other cases, but I don't know enough about MPD manifests or yt-dlp to say if you're missing something. But I'd be happy to move it to `_parse_mpd_formats_and_subtitles`.

> I tested it using: https://www.goplay.be/video/assisen/assisen-s1/assisen-s1-aflevering-6#autoplay
> 
> `python3 -m yt_dlp https://www.goplay.be/video/assisen/assisen-s1/assisen-s1-aflevering-6\#autoplay --username removed --password removed -f MERGED-093786da-a9ba-4c80-ac74-ff043139a312`
> 
> It only downloaded 22min 44seconds (full episode is 43:44)

Strange. Can you see how many fragments it downloads? 22:44 is the length of the first period, according to the manifest. 

For me it shows `[dashsegments] Total fragments: 1292`, which is the sum of the three periods, and gives me a 43:44 file. Does it work better if you also download the audio? (e.g., `-f wa+wv`?)

[download] 1.9% of ~ 672.59MiB at 1.38MiB/s ETA 08:47 (frag 24/1292) Looks like its also 1292 fragments Then I checked the file using VLC VLC is indeed showing the full 44min when scrolling to the end. But Mac details + Mac internal video player only shows 22min(see SS)

I see. Maybe there is something strange when you concatenate these streams. I only have VLC, for which it works, and ffmpeg also doesn't show any issues with the file.

I've now changed the code to skip the `init.mp4` initialization file in the follow-up periods. It's always at the start of the fragments of a period, so maybe your player runs into issues if that appears in the middle of the combined file. Does it work better now?

> I see. Maybe there is something strange when you concatenate these streams. I only have VLC, for which it works, and ffmpeg also doesn't show any issues with the file.
